docs.lead_paragraph: I can barely remember century's dawn, before my persona arrived. I had a job, I owed no debt, I rented an apartment, I wasn't married. My knees didn't hurt when it rained. Then I got involved with McSweeney's, which, according to most dictionaries, is an old Gaelic word meaning ''trendy literary scene.'' My role in this scene was simple: the fool. Both in the magazine and in person, I started calling myself ''the Greatest Living American Writer.'' This ''Neal Pollack'' was an arrogant oaf who'd been everywhere, written about everything and slept with everyone. The real me could lay claim only to the oaf bit. Yet somehow people got confused, or pretended to get confused. Because those were ironic years, I deliberately created some of the confusion. And then I started getting confused myself. If creating a literary alter ego were a mistake, then Kinky Friedman wouldn't be a serious candidate for governor of Texas. But, and I speak with a voice of authority here, if you're going to create such a persona, make it a likable one. To do otherwise is to invite ruin, or at least nasty e-mail messages. For the last five years, I've lived with a dark, obnoxious fictional version of myself. It's been an irritating time.
docs.snippet: Only the next morning, doubled over in an airport bathroom, did I understand. Dave Eggers had broken up with me.

docs.lead_paragraph: Natalie Beth Horowitz and Christopher John Prokop were married last evening at Bryant Park Grill in New York. Judge Richard M. Weinberg of the Criminal Court in New York officiated, and Judge Pauline Newman of the Federal Court of Appeals in Washington, the bride's great-aunt, participated in the ceremony. Mrs. Prokop, 28, is an assistant corporation counsel for the New York City Law Department, advising various city agencies on legal issues. She graduated from Cornell and received a law degree from New York University. She is a daughter of Daniel J. Horowitz of Rockville, Md., and the late Laura Horowitz. Her father retired as an Army physicist at Fort Belvoir, Va. Her mother founded Editorial Experts, an editorial services company now known as EEI Communications, in Alexandria, Va.
docs.snippet: Natalie Horowitz and Christopher Prokop were married on Saturday in New York.

docs.lead_paragraph: IF you read only the headlines, the future of globalization may seem scary, indeed. American jobs have already been heading abroad. And as telecommunications and more powerful computers enable companies to take even more jobs overseas, the service sector, which accounts for about 85 percent of the United States work force, will be increasingly vulnerable to competition from the cheap labor pools of the developing world.

headline.main: True or False: Outsourcing Is a Crisis

docs.snippet: As telecommunications and computing power expand, is America on the verge of losing oodles of white-collar jobs? Probably not.

docs.lead_paragraph: NO one wants to talk about it, and small wonder. The topic is health insurance, and the issue is the conversion of Horizon Blue Cross and Blue Shield -- the state-created entity that provides coverage for more than 3 million New Jerseyans -- to a for-profit company.

headline.main: Political Memo; When Will the State Cash In on Horizon?

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush came here on Friday to promote the Medicare drug benefit, enacted 18 months ago with help from AARP. But he was greeted by people protesting his plan to overhaul Social Security. ''Hands off our Social Security,'' said a sign outside the local community center, where Mr. Bush encouraged older Americans to sign up for the drug benefit.

headline.main: Bush, Touting Drug Plan, Encounters Protests Over Social Security

docs.snippet: The fight over Social Security could complicate efforts to sell the Medicare drug benefit, with confusion over actual and potential changes in the two programs.

docs.lead_paragraph: New York University is moving to close down its graduate students union at the end of the summer, the labor movement's only toehold among graduate students at private universities. Union officials quickly attacked N.Y.U. 's plan and vowed to fight the university in any way they could.

headline.main: N.Y.U. Moves to Disband Graduate Students Union

docs.snippet: New York University is moving to close down its graduate students union, the labor movement's only toehold among graduate students at private universities.

docs.lead_paragraph: Like many people who are determined to speak in epigrams, Suze Orman frequently talks nonsense. On her weekly financial-advice program, ''The Suze Orman Show,'' which appears Saturdays on CNBC, she splutters, prattles, drops words, mixes metaphors -- apparently driven to gibberish at the thought of what hapless debtors we Americans have become. It's an unusually effective spiel, especially when she follows it with measured advice about improving a credit rating, getting out of annuities and cooking dinner at home more often.

headline.main: For the Age of Do-It-Yourself Finance, She Wrote the Book(s) and the Programs

docs.abstract: Virginia Heffernan Critic's Notebook column on Suze Orman, who offers financial advice in books, on television and on lecture circuit; her latest book is titled The Money Book For the Young, Fabulous & Broke; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Suze Orman combines a humane approach and her knowledge of finance to create an unusually effective spiel in her weekly advice program on CNBC.

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: MONEY BOOK FOR THE YOUNG, FABULOUS & BROKE, THE (BOOK)

docs.lead_paragraph: And Enough Tomato Soup To Drown a Cow When we received the invitation to DAVID CHAPPELLE's party, we were beside ourselves with anticipation, eager to ask him about running off to South Africa, what happened there, and then, leaning forward and looking keenly into his eyes like BARBARA WALTERS, ask him what really happened there. Then someone pointed out that that we had misread the invitation, that it was to a screening with DAVID LACHAPELLE, the photographer and filmmaker, and we replied that of course we knew that, that we were actually referring to the plot of an obscure art film that had made the rounds when Mr. LaChapelle was working for ANDY WARHOL. And we quietly changed the subject.
docs.snippet: When we received the invitation to David Chappelle's party, we were beside ourselves with anticipation. Then someone pointed out that we had misread the invitation.

byline.original: By CAMPBELL ROBERTSON; With Melena Z. Ryzik and Luke Jerod Kummer

docs.lead_paragraph: Setting up a potential conflict with General Motors, the president of the United Automobile Workers union said Wednesday that he would not agree to change G.M.'s labor contract before it expires in 2007 or to roll back health benefits for G.M. hourly workers to match the lesser benefits of the company's salaried employees. In an extended interview the union's leader, Ron Gettelfinger, said that while he was willing to make concessions to help General Motors within the terms of their existing contract, the two sides were not yet close to reaching an agreement. G.M., he said, had not presented him with enough information to convince him of the severity of the financial situation.

headline.main: Tough Line By Union To G.M.

docs.abstract: United Automobile Workers' president Ron Gettelfinger, says he will not agree to change GM's labor contract before it expires in 2007 or roll back health benefits for GM hourly workers to match lesser benefits of company's salaried employees, interview; holds he is willing to make concessions to help GM within terms of existing contract; says GM has not presented him with enough information to convince him of severity of financial situation; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The president of the United Automobile Workers union said that he would not agree to change G.M.'s labor contract before it expires in 2007.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Paul Krugman's renewed call for a single-payer health care plan was another home run. I'd just like to add that insurance companies, emphasis on companies, are for-profit organizations. That profit is money that does not contribute to patient care, education or research.
